details.title: Strain energy imaging of a power MOS transistor using speckle interferometry

p: Stefan Dilhaire attended the University of Bordeaux in France, where he received both an undergraduate degree in microelectronics and a Ph.D. in electronics. He is now an assistant professor at the same university. His work involves the design of optical contactless probes for analyzing the thermal behavior of integrated circuits.

Wilfrid Claeys received the Ph.D. degree in 1974 at the University of Louvain, Belgium, where he became an assistant professor. He has been a professor at the University of Bordeaux, France, since 1990. He is leading a research group dedicated to optical probing of the thermal behavior of microelectronics components.

details.abstract: Mechanical characterization of electronic devices is often quite uneasy; most of the techniques used require a contact with the sample under study. In this paper, we propose an optical noncontact interferometric imaging method to study the thermomechanical behavior of running devices, and in particular, to deduce the corresponding elastic strain energy. This analysis will permit us to localize the zones of fragility of the device. Results obtained on a power MOS transistor to detect the region of maximum elastic strain energy are presented. It is in particular adapted in microelectronics applications to detect stress accumulation due to dilation coefficient mismatches when assembling microchips.

references.title: Thermomechanical deformation imaging of power devices by electronic speckle pattern interferometry (ESPI)

context.text: This work follows after measurements of the out-of-plane surface displacement using Electronic Speckle Pattern Interferometry (ESPI) [1], [2].

references.text: K. Nassim, L. Joannes, A. Cornet, S. Dilhaire, E. Schaub, W. Claeys, "Thermomechanical deformation imaging of power devices by electronic speckle pattern interferometry (ESPI)", Microelectronics Reliability, vol. 38, pp. 1341-1345, 1998.

references.title: Optical method for the measurement of the thermomechanical behavior of running electronic devices

context.text: This work follows after measurements of the out-of-plane surface displacement using Electronic Speckle Pattern Interferometry (ESPI) [1], [2].

references.text: S. Dilhaire, S. Jorez, A. Cornet, E. Schaub, W. Claeys, "Optical method for the measurement of the thermomechanical behavior of running electronic devices", Microelectronics Reliability, vol. 39, pp. 981-985, 1999.

references.title: Image-shearing camera for direct measurement of surface strains

context.text: A more detailed presentation of the shearography principle & the corresponding optical set-up are exposed in [3]–[6], as well as applications to surface strain analysis.

references.text: Y. Y. Hung, C. Y. Liang, "Image-shearing camera for direct measurement of surface strains", Applied Optics, vol. 18, no. 7, pp. 1046-1051, 1979.

references.title: Strain analysis by means of digital shearography: Potential, limitations and demonstration

context.text: A more detailed presentation of the shearography principle & the corresponding optical set-up are exposed in [3]–[4][6], as well as applications to surface strain analysis.

references.text: W. Steinchen, L. X. Yang, G. Kupfer, P. Mackel, F. Vossing, "Strain analysis by means of digital shearography: Potential limitations and demonstration", Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design, vol. 33, no. 2, pp. 171-182, 1998.

references.title: 3D shearography for surface strain analysis

context.text: A more detailed presentation of the shearography principle & the corresponding optical set-up are exposed in [3]–[5][6], as well as applications to surface strain analysis.

references.text: S. W. James, R. P. Tatam, "3D shearography for surface strain analysis", Proceedings of the SPIE̵The International Society for Optical Engineering, vol. 3783, pp. 247-256, 1999.

references.title: Thermal stress analysis of thermoelectric devices studied by speckle interferometry

context.text: A more detailed presentation of the shearography principle & the corresponding optical set-up are exposed in [3]–[6], as well as applications to surface strain analysis.

references.text: S. Dilhaire, S. Jorez, S. Grauby, L. D. P. Lopez, J.-M. Rampnoux, W. Claeys, "Thermal stress analysis of thermoelectric devices studied by speckle interferometry", Therminic 2001, 2001.
